qas.question: Before 1920, how would a person be white by law?

answers.text: if having seven-eights or more white ancestry

qas.question: What year was mulatto left off the US Census?
Who is responsible for the Census Bureau discarding the mulatto category?
When was a person legally white in South Carolina before 1920?
When was the one-drop rule ended?
What was an attempt to increase black political power?
What was the first year the U.S. Census used the mulatto category?

plausible_answers.text: enumerators were instructed to classify people in a binary way

qas.question: What was the result of a Northern-dominated Congress convincing the Census Bureau to change its rules?

context: In Virginia prior to 1920, for example, a person was legally white <a0_0>if having <b3_0>seven-eights or more white ancestry<b3_0/><a0_0/>. <b5_0>The one-drop rule<b5_0/> originated in some Southern United States in the <b4_0>late 19th century<b4_0/>, likely in response to whites' attempt to maintain white supremacy and limit black political power following the Democrats' regaining control of state legislatures in the late 1870s. The first year in which the U.S. Census dropped the mulatto category was <a1_0><b6_0>1920<b6_0/><a1_0/>; that year <b7_0>enumerators were instructed to classify people in a binary way<b7_0/> as white or black. This was a result of the <a2_0>Southern-dominated Congress<a2_0/> convincing the Census Bureau to change its rules.
